and  increases  in  government  taxes  and  duties  for  goods  and 
services (about 19% of the cost overrun).

implemented by communities, 100% of funding will be provided as 
a grant. The subsidiary loan from the Government to NWSDB will

The  main  benefits  of  the  Project  remain  (i)  improved  health; 
(ii) less  resources  (time  and  cash)  spent  by  households  in  water 
provision,  especially  by  women  and  young  girls;  and  (iii)  support 
to  environmentally  sustainable  economic  and  population  growth, 
especially  in  the  urban  centers.  By  reducing  child  mortality  and 
malnutrition  caused  by  waterborne  diseases,  and  increasing 
environmental  sustainability  through  a  reduction  of  groundwater 
overextraction and unsafe sanitation practices, the Project directly 
addresses ADB’s goal of poverty reduction and contributes to the 
achievement  of 
the  Millennium  Development  Goals.  Poor 
households are encouraged to participate as project beneficiaries.

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  two  proposed 
supplementary loans, both to the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka, for the Secondary 
Towns and Rural Community-Based Water Supply and Sanitation Project. 
 

II. 

THE APPROVED PROJECT 

A. 

The Context 

In  February  2002  a  ceasefire  agreement  was  signed  in  Sri  Lanka,  beginning  the  long 
2. 
process of negotiating a permanent end to a conflict which had affected the country for over 20 
years. Processed against this background, the Secondary Towns and Rural Community-Based 
Water Supply and Sanitation Project1 presented a balanced investment proposal whereby much 
needed  water  infrastructure  (a  key  element  for  convergence)  was  to  be  provided  to  deprived 
towns  in  both  the  east  and  south  of  the  country.  Furthermore,  in  December  2004,  the  Indian 
Ocean tsunami impacted coastal areas of the Southern and North-East provinces, significantly 
affecting  towns  supported  under  the  Project.  Despite  varying  levels  of  dialogue  experienced 
since  the  approval  of  the  Project  and  a  decline  in  the  security  situation  over  the  past  few 
months,  the  provision  of  safe  drinking  water  and  adequate  sanitation  systems  to  poor 
households remains one of the highest priorities for all stakeholders. 
 
B. 

Project Rationale 

3. 
Notwithstanding a significant increase in the population percentage with access to safe 
water sources, from 68% in 1994 to 77% in 2000,2 only about 30% has a household connection 
to a piped system while 10% of the population is covered by hand pump tube wells.3 Similarly, 
urban population with access to improved sanitation increased from 89% to 98% from 1990 to 
2002 while rural coverage rose from 64% to 89%. Overall, 80% of the population has access to 
on-site  sanitation  facilities  but  wastewater  collection  and  disposal  systems  are  not  widely 
available.4 Although  groundwater  quality  in  most  parts  of  the  country  is  of  reasonable  quality, 
biological contamination, high levels of fluoride and salinity intrusion in wells and water intakes 
are  common  problems.  Urban  growth  has  increased  pressure  on  scarce  water  resources, 
stressing  the  need  to  expedite  provision  of  piped  water  supply.  Towns  such  as  Batticaloa, 
Hambantota, and Muttur are located in water scarce areas where water quantity is limited and 
quality frequently does not meet required standards. At the time of appraisal (September 2002), 
more than 40% of households had incomes below the poverty line in Polonnaruwa, Batticaloa, 
and  Muttur;  in  Hambantota,  approximately  25%  of  households  were  poor.  Poverty  and  lack  of 
access to services were found to be highly correlated among sample populations in all project 
towns. In Hambantota, 45% of households had access to piped water, but this figure was as low 
as  19%  for  Polonnaruwa,  4%  for  Batticaloa,  and  0%  for  Muttur.  The  incidence  of  water  and 
sanitation  related  diseases  were  found  to  be  highest  among  populations  where  a  higher 
percentage  of  households  lacked  private  sanitation  facilities.  The  incidence  of  water-related 
diseases was found to be highest in Muttur, affecting almost 40% of surveyed households.5

C. 

Objectives and Scope 

5. 
In  March  2002,  the  Government  and  ADB  signed  a  poverty  reduction  partnership 
agreement,  highlighting  the  importance  of  access  to  safe  water  supply  and  sanitation  in 
reducing poverty in Sri Lanka. On 16 January 2003, ADB approved a loan equivalent to $60.3 
million  from  ADB's  Special  Funds  resources  for  the  Secondary  Towns  and  Rural  Community 
Based Water Supply and Sanitation Project (footnote 1). The loan was declared effective on 21 
November 2003 and the project completion date set to be 30 September 2009. The goal of this 
Project  is  to  reduce  poverty  and  promote  human  development  by  reducing  the  incidence  of 
waterborne  diseases  and  by  reducing  the  time  and  resources  that  households  spend  in 
acquiring water. Its objective is to provide safe drinking water and safe sanitation to people in 
project  areas.  The  Project  will  increase  the  capacity  of  water  sector  institutions  to  operate, 
maintain, augment existing water schemes and invest in new water schemes in rural and urban 
areas.  The  Project  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  water  policy, 8  as  it  fosters  the  necessary 
improvement and expansion of delivery services in Sri Lanka, promotes conservation of water, 
improved operational and financial efficiency and governance. The Project aims to provide 24-
hour supply in all four urban areas, and supports the Government’s efforts in providing access 
to improved sanitation facilities for all through its urban and rural sanitation components. 
 
6. 
Outcome  and  Outputs. The Project was designed to improve the standard of living in 
rural areas of Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa districts in the North Central Province; and in the 
towns  of  Batticaloa  and  Muttur  in  the  North-East  Province,  Hambantota  and  Matara  in  the 
Southern  Province,  and  Polonnaruwa  in  the  North  Central  Province.  The  Project  is  also 
designed to increase the financial and institutional sustainability of NWSDB and the institutional 
capacity  of  provincial  councils,  Pradeshiya  Sabhas  (PSs),  and  CBOs  participating  in  the 
Project.  The  project  design,  as  originally  defined,  anticipates  accomplishment  of  three 
components, related outputs and activities. 
 
7. 
Component  1  (urban  component)  anticipates:  (i)  provision  of  new  piped  water  supply 
systems and improved drainage in the towns of Batticaloa and Muttur, (ii) expansion of existing 
water  supply  systems  in  the  towns  of  Polonnaruwa  and  Hambantota,  (iii)  construction  of  a 
salinity  barrier  at  the  intake  in  Matara  to  prevent  saline  intrusion  during  dry  periods, 
(iv)  provision of wastewater collection and treatment for Batticaloa Hospital, (v) improvement of 
drainage  schemes  in  the  most  densely  populated  areas  of  Batticaloa  and  Muttur,  and 
(vi) provision of a low-cost latrine program.

social  services  exacerbates  income  and  non-income  poverty,  particularly  in  project  towns 
affected by the tsunami. The Project is expected to impact on public health, reducing the high 
incidence of intestinal parasite and waterborne diseases caused by poor sanitation and lack of 
safe water. This benefit will accrue especially to infants and children, who are more vulnerable. 
The  Project  will  reduce  the  time  women  spend  fetching  water  and  taking  care  of  children 
suffering  from  waterborne  diseases,  and  the  burden  of  carrying  heavy  loads.  The  Project  will 
continue  to  pursue  the  gender  action  plan’s  specific  targets,  enhancing  women’s  role  and 
participation in the sector. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 14.

The  Project  will  continue  to  provide  beneficiaries  with  training  opportunities  and  experience  in

Environmental  Sustainable  Development.  Towns  supported  under  the  Project  are 
located  in  Sri  Lanka’s  “dry  zone”.  The  Project  will  support  water  extraction  from  sustainable 
sources,  limiting  pressures  on  groundwater  resources;  and  incorporate  measures  to  prevent 
salinity intrusion and protect ecosystems. The Project will also provide improved sanitation and, 
in the case of Batticaloa, sewage treatment facilities preventing indiscriminate discharge of raw 
sewage  into  adjacent  lagoons.  Lagoon  and  river  protection  is  expected  to  yield  direct  benefits 
on downstream ecosystems and, since primary fishing activities engage a significant part of the 
labor force, protecting fisheries is a central activity for proposed poverty strategies.  
 
Economic  Benefits  and  Financial  Sustainability.  Economic  and  financial  analyses 
64. 
were carried out for each water supply scheme in four towns (Supplementary Appendixes L, M, 
and  N).  Economic  benefits  for  water  supply  were  quantified  and  the  economic  internal  rate  of

Polonnaruwa (7.9%), and Hambantota (6.2%) in order of economic viability. For the four water 
supply  schemes  combined,  the  overall  EIRR  is  estimated  at  9.8%.  As  agreed  with  the

capable  of  recovering:  (i)  O&M,  debt  service,  and  depreciation  for  all  schemes  within  the 
country;  and  (ii)  scheme-specific  O&M.  Sustainability  of  the  rural  schemes  has  been  secured 
through:  (i)  CBO  signed  agreements  to  operate  and  maintain  all  schemes;  and  (ii)  extensive 
CBO  capacity  development  activities,  which  include  O&M,  management,  and  financial  and 
accounting training during construction and operation phases.

At  appraisal,  design  criteria  for  water  supply  components  was  set  to  be  2025,  but  the  water  resource  horizon  has  been

priority  actions  to  rapidly  provide  water  to  tsunami-affected  resettlements,  water  treated  in  existing  plant  (7,500  m3/day) 
should be supplemented by a water treatment plant sponsored by the Government of Austria that produces 7,500 m3/day . 
The  water  treatment  plant  financed  by  ADB  has  been  resized  to  provide  15,000  m3/day.  Electromechanical  works  and 
reservoirs are to be constructed to serve all 3 plants. A Single (600 mm diameter) raw water main has been replaced by 2 x 
300 mm water mains for the Government of Austria-financed and existing water treatment plants, and a 500 mm diameter 
DI for the new plant. Given land restrictions within the site, a mechanical sludge dewatering system is required instead of

Water Distribution. As a result of an increase in the diameter of transmission mains, and to withstand internal pressure, 
piping material has been changed from PVC to DI in various sections. A 500 mm DI treated water transmission main from 
Ambalantota  to  Mirijjawila  has  been  separated  from  the  main  package.  Extension  to  the  distribution  system  required 
accommodation/modification of service areas after the tsunami and the introduction of a coastal protection buffer zone. 
Source (Unnichchai tank) sustainability and security of supply was checked during feasibility, and confirmed during detailed 
design. Detailed engineering design demonstrated that expansion of the tank’s capacity only required raising the dam wall 
by 5.0 feet instead of 7.5 feet, as initially indicated at feasibility; consequent size reduction of the water intake would result 
from  change  in  design  capacity  and  concept  using  submersible  pumps.  The  access  bridge  from  the  intake  well  to  the 
abutment of the tank was newly accommodated for pump maintenance.  
 
Water Treatment. Following a monthly monitoring program, which included testing for algae (and potentially toxic strains of 
blue-green algae), the water treatment plant design had to be modified to include treatment against the potential seasonal 
presence of cyanobacteria. The water treatment plant will now include dissolved air floatation activated carbon adsorption 
(PAC) and chlorination. In addition, sludge lagoons had to be incorporated into the design of the plant. The capacity of the 
water treatment plant reduced from 54,000 cum/day to 40,000 cum/day after reassessment of non-revenue water.  
 
Transmission  Mains.  Following  geotechnical  investigations,  which  indicated  the  presence  of  hard  rock  near  the  road 
surface, partial rock excavation for casing of the raw water transmission mains will be required in several selected sections. 
Treated water transmission mains will be encased in cement structures and laid across the lagoons instead of anchored on 
existing bridges, given their precarious conditions and their location in security sensitive areas.  
 
Distribution  Network.  The  viability  of  electromechanical  works  was  reviewed  and  modified,  resulting  in  requirements  of 
one  additional  pumping  station  and  one  additional  groundwater  reservoir.  Distribution  systems  were  reviewed  to 
accommodate  tsunami  resettlement  area  demands.  The  number  of  distribution  pumps  increased  from  (2+1  stand  by)  to 
(4+2 standby). The total number of elevated towers remains the same, but capacity has been increased by 50%. The total 
size of the distribution network was reevaluated since feasibility, requiring 40% additional length (from 183 km to 261 km).

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Sri Lanka:  
 
Sri  Lanka  ranked  84th  among  174  countries  in  the  2000  United  Nations  human  development  index.  The  percentage  of 
poor households fell from 18.2% to 13.4% in urban areas from 1992 to 1996. In the same period, the percentage of poor 
households declined in rural areas. Despite impressive achievements, poverty levels in Sri Lanka remain high. Poverty is 
multifaceted and is manifested in the ability to afford basic consumption goods, and lack of access to basic needs such as 
safe  drinking  water,  sanitation  facilities,  health  care,  and  education.  In  recent  years,  water-related  diseases  and  child 
malnutrition have worsened. Twenty-eight percent of the population does not have access to safe drinking water and 24% 
does not have access to safe sanitation. There are regional variations in dimensions of poverty, with poverty levels in the 
northeast among the highest in the nation. In some districts, including Muttur, over half of the rural population does not 
have  access  to  safe  drinking  water  supplies.  Inadequate  sanitation  infrastructure  and  access  to  safe  drinking  water  in 
urban and rural areas are the leading causes of public health problems in poor communities. 
 
The  Government’s  2002  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  states  that  “the  provision  of  safe  drinking  water,  and  adequate 
sewage and sanitation systems, is frequently cited as the single, highest social service priority by poor households.” The 
strategy  includes  provision  of  water  to  85%  of  the  population  by  2010.  In  April  2002,  the  Government  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) signed a poverty partnership agreement that recognizes water supply and sanitation as a main 
strategy for poverty reduction.

What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Poverty consultations carried out in Sri Lanka by the Poverty Impact Monitoring Unit on behalf of ADB indicate that the 
poor unanimously identify basic infrastructure, including water supply and sanitation, as a priority need. 
 
The project area includes both urban and rural areas from east, south, and north central regions of the country. There has 
been a significant deterioration in the general economic, social, and physical conditions in the northeast region over the 
past two decades because of ethnic conflict and war; and poverty is quantitatively and qualitatively different from that in 
other  parts  of  the  country.  Although  no  official  statistics  are  available  for  this  region  because  the  security  situation  is 
unfavorable, the project socioeconomic surveys show that in Batticaloa and Muttur in the Northeast Province, poverty is 
higher than in the rest of the country, there is a high concentration of ethnic minorities, health indicators are lower, and the 
situation is more acute in Muttur. Therefore, 74% of the capital investment of the Project will concentrate in the northeast, 
where  investments  in  basic  infrastructure  have  been  suspended  for  the  last  20  years  and  poverty  is  greater.  In 
Polonnaruwa  and  Anurapurah  districts,  the  poverty  incidence  is  8%  higher  than  the  national  figurea  and  is  the  third 
poorest province based on the higher poverty line. Within the districts, poverty is higher in rural areas, which are targeted 
in the rural component. The Project will prioritize rural investments based on demand-driven and need criteria. 
 
Four  of  the  five  project  districts  are  in  the  northeast  and  north  central  regions.  In  these  four  districts,  40–45%  of  the 
people  live  below  poverty  line.  Hambantota  in  the  south  has  a  high  incidence  of  drought  and  limited  groundwater.

Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
The  Project  recognizes  that  women’s  participation  in  decision  making  is  important,  as  they  are  providers,  users,  and 
managers of water at the household level. Women are the best people in a village household to ask about the quantity, 
quality,  and reliability of  water used  by her family. The Project also recognizes that communication  and interaction  with 
women  is  more  effective  when  done  by  other  women;  consequently,  it  is  important  to  include  women  in  the 
implementation  team.  Therefore,  the  Project  will  actively  encourage  the  participation  of  women  as  beneficiaries  and 
implementers. 
 
During  social  mobilization  at  selected  villages,  the  importance  of  women’s  participation  will  be  explained  to  beneficiary 
communities in village meetings, hygiene education, and all other project activities. The following targets will be achieved 
in the implementation of the rural component: 
 
 
 
 

(i)  Project facilitators will emphasize the need to have active participation of all at community meetings, including 
50% participation by women. 
(ii) Women will account for 50% participation in small group activities. 
(iii) The executive committee of the CBOs will be at least 50% women.
